Beta review - 26.01.16

You can't help comparing Tides of Numenera with its spiritual predecessor Planescape: Torment. For good or ill, this is not PS:T 2. Without Avellone, there is a noticeable shift in writing and the setting itself greatly differs from Planescape. I had worried that it would be a pale imitation, a weak creation that mimics but does not understand what made Planescape: Torment so great.

I was wrong. I am not very far in the game, but after having talked to many NPCs and finished several quests, I feel like I have a good gauge of Tides of Numenera.

1. The writing is superb. I still miss Avellone, but the new writers raise many interesting questions about legacy, always finding a new unusual facet to explore and introduce you to. It's not a shallow game, which comes as a great relief to me.

2. The choices are introspective. The game not only asks what you would do, but why and how? It is very refreshing to be asked to ponder on my motives, especially compared to Pillars of Eternity, whose choices took a more results and action oriented view.

3. The gameplay and combat looks promising. I can't say more, as the game is yet unbalanced and I only experienced 2 crisises yet.

4. Bugs and lack of optimization. Currently, the game lags pretty hard 3-year old gaming laptop. The loading times are exruciating. Smaller levels need 3-5 minutes, the big marketplace requires whole 10-15 minutes.

Overall, I recommend the game, but only buy it right now if you have either an extremely powerful PC or a lot of patience for the loading times. I had the patience, but doubt that many other people will.

I've put in a decent chunk of time in to the Torment beta over the weekend and while its obviously clunky and unfinished I had a great deal of fun with it.

There are so many people you can talk to in Sagus, the first city, that you can easily spend over 5 hours just going around and annoying people with endless questions. Best thing about it is that pretty much every single bit of dialogue is well written and all of the characters have some sort of compelling story to tell, if you can get them to share it.

For example there's a cannibalistic cult that lives in the depths of the city and rather than the usual RPG business of having you kill them Torment actually managed to convince me to not just leave them alone but concede that they might have a good point...

However, while the story really is amazing, possibly just as good or even better than Planescape: Torment's the combat, graphics and performance still need a lot of work done to them.

The combat right now is best described as generic low-level DND combat with the one big difference being the various items and background objects you can use (the titular Numenera) if you have either the necessary skill or knowledge to activate them without blowing yourself up in the process. I'm guessing things will become a whole lot more interesting once you get a few more abilities under your belt but since you're mostly stuck as a low level character during the beta it was fairly meek.

The performance is also a bit of a sore spot. Its not uncommon to have your game freeze for a couple of seconds mid combat or while interacting with particularly complex background objects or even when simply accessing your inventory or any menu besides the dialogue one.

In other words, while Torment has an amazing story that's well worth exploring, it is still very much so a beta and as such I'd recommend you buy it either because you want to support the developers or because you want to soak in the story. Just don't buy it expecting a finished game because it most certainly isn't one just yet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You're sitting in a room, alone.  Before you hover images, passing in rapid sequence, but conveying a comforting sense of the entirety of a whole.  You sift through their details - an odd protuberance in an unexpected place, a comforting voice passing through the air behind you - and ponder.  While you draw no closer to these images physically, your mind and will are progressively and inexorably more deeply involved in the events you observe, these same events you even direct, to some extent.  You notice that, in reflections of reflections, you weigh heavy questions.  They pass through lesser used corridors in your mind, and prompt at once both introspection and alarm.  You realize then that you just spent the greater part of an afternoon, and the equivalent of the price of a quality meal for two, on a simulacrum, still in its fledgling state, of worlds only known to a glimmering few, and you yearn to know - to feel - more.

If you've read this far, congratulations.  You'll see more like this, lots more, as you wade, wander, and weigh your options through this newest world of Torment.

After starting over twice, and a good, what, 30 hours at this point?  I finally found an in-canon expositor who at least helped me, the human playing this game, understand that numenera is a plural noun indicating objects, not a singular proper noun indicating a place.  I know what two of the five tides regard, and my latest protagonist is happily balanced among all of them.

[Edit] So, I am apparently a ponderously slow exploratory player, and I'm okay with that.  I do believe the reason the series is named Torment is because it's (almost) impossible to die.  That seems fitting, for someone who took almost 50 hours to get through the beta.  Pro tip: don't leave town.

Having resolved 16-odd quests, and with 2 remaining, now I'm seriously jonesing to get on with the rest of this.  I can only guess that, as a secret-finder and prose-reader (I really LIKE the Meres!), I'll probably lose ~200 hours of my life in this game.  I can't wait for the hideous stench of the Bloom to fill my nostrils... ugh, wait, maybe I can? [/edit]

Highly recommended for your Bartle's exploratory types!  Feel free to look elsewhere for bullet-time, spraying gibs, skimpy outfits, collisions, porridge, wanton violence or wontons.  You're on earth, a billion years in the future, and you've got all the time in the world to read through tomes of narrative, linking slender chains in your mind, piecing together yourself, and all the whys of all the voids, within and without.

Grand. Fictional. Terrifying. Alluring. Fun. Interesting. Human.

The beta is a bit rough, but it's the first beta build so that's just going to happen.  That said, it was still very playable and enjoyable.  What really struck me about the game was the sense of otherness that the main city oozed out of each and every one of its pores.  Even after investigation I don't know what half of the ancient machines that scatter the city do, but they're all beautiful and intriguing.

Remember those question based character creation segments in a lot of older RPGs?  Well this game found a way to take that concept and make it not suck.  Basically how you solve the games initial set of problems determines your class and early stats in a way that feels organic.  You're literally discovering yourelf.  Don't worry, though, if you don't like the results, you get a chance to change them to what you want to play before jumping into the game world proper.

I don't have a solid review of the game's combat, because I didn't really fight anyone per se.  I wanted to see if you could solve everything without dealing a single HP of damage, and for everything I stumbled upon that was an option!

The strongest point of the beta is probably the writing.  It was a delight!

No this is not a direct sequel to Planscape Torment, but it has some the people working on it who worked on the old Planscape Torment (which is imo one of the greatest rpgs ever and the best writing ever in a videogame).

So this game has alot to live up to, but so far it is on track to become a classic crpg. It is fun to play and so far the dialogue is very interesting. Also its good to see that you can skip out on some of the combat still.

Only have little over 2 hours on the game so far but I am very impressed. I liked the new crpgs like Divinity Original Sin, Wasteland 2 and Pillars of Eternity that have come from Kickstarter and this new Torment is no different. A little rough around the edges but sooo much to love!

If you liked the resurgence of crpgs the last few years, check this one out! It is still being wokred on and the full game is not finished yet, but what is here now is a wonderful taste of whats to come. Chris Avellone was also helping with the writing for this game, so if you liked his writing on Planscape Torment, Alpha Protocol, KOTOR2 or Fallut New vegas, check this one out!

The only real negatives I have atm, for a beta like this is that the controls need some work, its a little slow/clunky/unresponsive when you move around and sometimes you get stuck on elements of the game world sometimes. The UI needs alot of work and there are a hand full of bugs as expected. Still, these are a few issues that don't ruin the game and that I am sure will be improved/fixed while the game is being made and when it hits full release, as other crpgs in early access have done in the past (Pillars, Wasteland 2, Divinity,etc..). So far it is a great start though I must say!

We have more Torment people! And it is so far so good! Time to celebrate!!! I will update this review as more updates and content comes out and as I spend more time with it. So far though, the good FAR outweighs the bad! If you love reading high quality dialogue and story stuff, pick this up asap. If you like Inexile games pick this up... if you liked Planscape Torment pick this up! If you want to wait till its 100% done by all means join in the party later. But so far for a early beta of an rpg it is good and has a ton of potential when the full came is released. Some of the best writing around already, can only imagine the full game.

I have played the first bits of the game and so far, I am very much impressed. The writing is top-notch, and it really brought back those times when an RPG game really puts you in the shoes of your character. The amount of lore, the presence of literary power, and philosophical queries places this game in my list of video games as gesamntkunstwerk (total art), as an experience. To sum up, this is the type of game you should buy and play because it immerses you into a world that is merely a reflection of our own. The decisions of the Last Castoff are refractions of your decisions in your own life. I think video games (open-ended/open-world RPG's in particular [tho T:ToN is more open-ended]) are an existential commodity that serves as a prism to our own experiences in life. And with the emergence of games like Torment: Tides of Numenera, I think its players will get to answer questions about individuality, the weight of their choices in this tapestry of life, and most importantly, they will get a glimpse of the essence of their existence.

Contains spoilers. You were warned.

To those who think im being unreasonable or just hating on the game: please go back to your fallouts 4, wastelands 2 and other garbage hailed as universal masterpiece. If however you played things like Consortium, Age of Decadence, Silent Storm Sentinels, Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines or had an irl roleplaying adventure with a competent DM, and enjoyed them, - you are likely to agree with me here. The game is at best a 7/10, despite all the promises and hollow boasts at how incredible its gonna be, it doesnt deliver. It hasnt delivered the experienced it strived and promised to. If you disagree with that, hey im happy you are happy with the game, because i am not.

I have concearns about this game. I absolutely love the concept, how its realised however... i played just one hour got annoyed with some things to be honest. A lot of people are giving this a 10/10 straight up, talking about how great it is, and for the most part its pretty solid, however: there is room for doubt. During my 1st launch i died before spawning, *spoilers* you are ejected from a sort of cocoon down the planet, so i figured might aswell get there faster. Dead. But if you sit around in midair pondering existance you dont die despite falling god knows the distance. Now ingame the reason for why you die in one condition and dont in another : Terminal velocity, nevermind the distance its the speed that kills you. Great.

Moving on: the tutorial is a cluster♥♥♥♥ and in theory as you see memories of others it could be incredible, what it fails to do however is give any sort of direction or motivation. Oh hey its another faceless husk i never seen before and i get to decide what happens... oh boy, where you pretty much select what stat you want to increase, which is probably far from what you would have done if you gave 2 ♥♥♥♥♥ about the characters involved.

Writing is top notch with a few bumps here and there but its all too ♥♥♥♥ing convenient. Oh hey check it out! There are 5 tanks and consoles, oh gee and 5 enemies 1 per console who could have guessed. Oh and the radiant light vanquishes yeh yeh great tides n stuff.

I sat there for an hour (or less i might have went to cook something) being bored out of my mind and i love rpgs. I had no empathy to anyone involved for all i care the characters should have all died. It wasnt some intense situation there is no sense of urgency or impact or pretty much anything other then tedium forced upon you. QUICK THERE IS NO TIME TO EXPLAIN GET THIS DONE! OH YOU WANT TO KNOW MORE? WELL LET ME TALK TO YOU ABOUT IT FOR 20 MINUTES WE GOT TIME! You just proceed at your own convenience, where is the monsters starting attack midsentese because you are ♥♥♥♥ing too slow? Where is need to survive? Why should i care for a hundred characters im gonna see for just 20 seconds of screen time?

Its 2d and yet it lags like no other. There is no optimisation whatsowhever. And on top of all that, they hired Mitsoda to help them sink this boat.

The game has a great potential, it can be amazing, hell i ONLY saw tutorial, nothing more but it was enough for me to be dissuaded from exploring any more at least till they release this.

Its a no for me atm, only people i can recommend this to are avid RPG fans, game has some interesting things to offer, but not too many and are outweighted by all the negatives.
